intro: Halodule pinifolia, commonly known as Florida seagrass, is a marine flowering plant found in shallow coastal waters of the western Atlantic. It belongs to the family Poaceae and is characterized by its grass-like appearance with narrow, linear leaves. The plant forms dense underwater meadows that provide critical habitat for various marine species. Halodule pinifolia plays a vital role in stabilizing sediments and improving water quality through its extensive root system. It is also an important component of seagrass ecosystems, supporting biodiversity and coastal resilience.
